Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185A.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185A and the court’s venue rules because the rented premises and Defendant are located in Worcester.

Marini v. Ireland, 373 Mass. 1 (1977) (r.raw_text: Marini v. Ireland, 373 Mass. 1 (1977) (recognizing landlord duties regarding habitability and tenants’ remedies)
Marini v. Ireland, 373 Mass. 1 (1977) (r.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord implicitly warrants the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and must take reasonable steps to maintain the premises in a condition fit for habitation and to abate conditions that materially interfere with tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Marini v. Ireland, 373 Mass. 1 (1977) (r.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case concerning evidentiary and procedural issues in a murder prosecution. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, implied warranties of habitability, or the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a landlord’s implied warranty to maintain habitable premises or to abate conditions interfering with a tenant’s use and enjoyment.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (discussing habitability and remedies)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord implicitly warrants the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment of the leased premises and must take reasonable steps to maintain the premises in a condition fit for habitation and to abate conditions that materially interfere with tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition is explicitly about Massachusetts law and an implied warranty of quiet enjoyment and habitability. Hilder v. St. Peter is a Vermont Supreme Court decision recognizing an implied warranty of habitability under Vermont law; it does not interpret Massachusetts statutes or common law duties of quiet enjoyment. While it approvingly quotes Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway (a Massachusetts case), Hilder itself is not authority for what Massachusetts law requires and thus does not support the proposition as stated.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will. Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199, 293 N.E.2d 831, 843 (1973).”

105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: The presence of rodents and repeated rodent droppings in a tenant’s kitchen constitutes a substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises and with habitability and sanitary living conditions.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.raw_text: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (California Supreme Court authority addressing landlord obligations and tenant remedies)
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: The law governing the covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord obligations to maintain habitability, and tenant remedies in Massachusetts and persuasive authority include, but are not limited to:
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a leading California Supreme Court case that recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, discusses the evolution from traditional property concepts (including constructive eviction and quiet enjoyment) toward contract-based obligations, and details tenant remedies such as rent withholding and use of the warranty as a defense in unlawful detainer. Although it is not a Massachusetts case, it expressly cites and relies on the Massachusetts decision Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway as part of a national trend, making it strong persuasive authority on habitability, quiet enjoyment-related doctrines, and tenant remedies. Thus it fits within the proposition’s reference to law in Massachusetts and persuasive authority on these topics.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. This implied warranty of habitability does not require that a landlord ensure that leased premises are in perfect, aesthetically pleasing condition, but it does mean that “bare living requirements” must be maintained.
